Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List:
When I would do all the readings: 5+
When I would do more of a skim of the readings: ~2
The reading lists were lengthy, but they were well curated and easy to follow. I spent on average 5-6 hours on the reading reflections each week.
5-10 for readings and discussion preparation.
(averaged with the amount of time spent on final paper) 15

Strengths: Amazing topic that all public health students should learn about, very engaged professor and TA, course material is nicely organized and built on decades of experience 
Weaknesses: Way too many readings per week for any student to reasonably do, a little too much emphasis on student-led discussions where more input from Professor Geballe would be helpful
variety is its strength and weakness, as we had to prepare with huge reading materials, could use less materials, but good to have a reference collection for future use

Amazing. It's such a shame that Shelley won't be teaching this course any longer. Great news that the content is being integrated into the core requirements -- I only hope whoever teaches the new course does it justice. They have big shoes to fill.

I think this is such an important course to have at YSPH. Having taken the new Health Equity and Social Justice course, as well as this one, I think this one is such an important part of the curriculum and goes much more in-depth than HESJ does alone. 

I wish the format of the course consisted of less student presentations and more Shelley's teaching. She was such a valuable resource of experience that I feel we missed out on a bit.

Strengths: course content, discussion

Weaknesses: cut back on readings

Strengths- Really interesting material, that is important to understand in the Public Health field and extremely passionate professor
Weaknesses- timing/structure could have been improved. The presentations were based on rough draft of our paper, however given that you basically needed to have a fully formed paper to present a meaningful, and sound piece of work this was somewhat hard because many of the professor and peer comments would require lots of time to research and fix (in time for the final paper due date, not presentations). I wonder if it would be helpful to have the presentations require students to present on their final paper (due earlier in the semester).
Amazing course- loved how much time we spent discussing topics and the readings each week. I learned so much from my peers and Shelley through this course.
This was by far one of my favorite courses at YSPH. The material was indepth, and we really engaged with thoughtful and actionable readings that helped prepare me for a future PH career.
Amazing!!
Such an assignment course. A true shame it wont be taught by Shelley next year. I urge the school to find someone who can teach it though. I learned so much
This is an amazing class. It takes into consider upstream and downstream factors that contribute to both disparities and inequities, and allows students to pick an important topic to dive into.
Shelley is a phenomenal instructor. It was a valuable part ofthr curriculum, but at times too introductory.
Such an amazing course. I am sad that it will not be offered next year, but I understand that it makes the most sense since it is not a part of the core.
Shelley is one of the best professors I had during my time at YSPH.  She provides students with helpful materials and resources for the course and creates an engaging classroom experience.
Fascinating course that covered extremely important topics in public health.

This course was everything I could have hoped for. It was so well-presented and structured. Great balance of discussion and material review. Loved the incorporation of current debates, including supreme court rulings and changes in the law.

Shelley is one of the best professors I have had at Yale. She is an expert on the topic of health disparities and conveys its importance well to students. She has a wealth of knowledge which she disseminates through articles and resources she has amassed over the years. She also cares a lot about individual students and makes an effort to get to know us.
excellent teacher, very knowledgeable
Amazing, incredible, 500% devoted. I can't imagine a more dedicated or passionate teacher (and I've done A LOT of years in school.)

Shelley is perhaps the best professor I have ever had the pleasure of learning from. Her knowledge, expertise, passion, and genuine care for and belief in her students is unparalleled. She leads by example and her people-centered focus never wavers. Shelley has been such an inspiration to me and I will always carry what she has taught me throughout my career in public health and my life.
Amazing instructor-- created safe environment to grapple with difficult issues.
Strengths: amazing professor, genuinely cares about students

Strengths- so kind, passionate, knowledgeable and definitely the one professor at ysph who truly cares for/invests in/takes the time to get to know her students
Weaknesses- none!; If at all, would prefer more time for lecture from Shelley given her knowledge, and cut back on some of the student discussion.

Best professor I have ever had. She cares so much about students perspectives, and genuinely wants everyone to learn and engage within their passions. The feedback she provides on all of our work is amazing, and makes everyone feel as if she truly values the time and effort we put into each assignment.
Professor Geballe is truly amazing and outstanding. Take any class with her that you can.
She is an incredible teacher!
Shelley deserves a shrine at ysph

Shelley is AMAZING! At first, I was only taking this class because I know how great Shelley is, but her passion for health disparities was very salient throughout the entire course, making it a very enjoyable and informative class.

Shelley is the backbone of YSPH - she is wonderful and I cannot sing her praise enough. She is a wealth of knowledge and one of the kindest people I have met since moving to the East Coast. Course discussions are always interesting and engaging.
Amazing. Best instructor ever.

Shelley is very passionate about health disparities and it shows during her lectures.  She is very good at bringing in outside materials into conversation to provoke further discussion and thought from students.
One of the most amazing instructors that I have had a Yale so far.

Shelley puts SO MUCH effort into everything she does, from the syllabus and reading list to the presentations. I learned so much from her and my peers, and it is certainly thanks to her that we had the opportunity to think through difficult questions.
Highly recommend this course to complete any student's public health training. Expect to dedicate a fair amount of time to get more out of this class.
if you are interested in disparities and SBH then this course is a must! highly recommended
Excellent. So crucial. Needs to be required, so it makes sense that the class is becoming a core requirement. I only hope the content successfully translates.

I would 100% recommend this class to a fellow student. I understand this is Shelley's last year teaching the course, and I hope someone else picks it up, or more elements from this course are incorporated into the new Health Equity & Social Justice required course. I feel if Shelley and Trace were able to collaborate in the design, there could be the potential for a really excellent core course for students.
Great overview of social justice in public health; you will learn how to analyze policy landscapes and make new recommendations
An eye-opening course that looks at complex, root causes of current health disparities led by an all-around amazing professor

I'd highly encourage any second-year students to take this course. Although there are quite a few readings, they are all so interesting and class each week is both stimulating and thought-provoking. Every YSPH student should try and take a course with Shelley before graduating!!
Very indepth and political lens to health disparities. Would highly recommend to anyone.
If it were being offered again I would say definitely take it!

This class looks at the various factors that contribute to health disparities and health inequities. Not only do we learn what disparities and inequities exist, but we learn ways and think of ideas for how to remedy these disparities, both through policy and practice.
Take any course with Shelley.
A very thorough overview of health disparities- from their structural causes down to the health disparities themselves.
I would highly recommend to every student.
